intro.para: Roughly speaking, a subvector space of \RNr[n] is a copy of \RNr[k], k\leq n sitting inside \RNr[n]. We approach subvector spaces from two points of view:

li.para:
Geometrically, a subvector space of \RNr[n] appears as line, or a plane, or a copy of \RNr[k], k\leq n,
passing through the origin
Example
So, in particular, a hyperspace of \RNr[n] is a subvector space of \RNr[n], while a general hyperplane is not a subvector space of \RNr[n].
.

Algebraically, a subvector space of \RNr[n] appears as a collection of vectors V which is
closed under the operations of addition and scalar multiplication
See an illustration of this
. This means that the sum of any two vectors from V is again in V, and an arbitrary scalar multiple of a vector in V by a numbers is again in V.

intro.para:
What leads us to consider subvector spaces of \RNr[n]? We encounter two primary sources of them. The first source is the ‘ span construction
What is ‘span’?
The span of a collection S of vectors in \RNr[n] is the smallest subvector space of \RNr[n] containing S. – For example, the span of two vectors \Vect{u} and \Vect{v} is the collection of all vectors of the form
s\cdot \Vect{u} + t\cdot \Vect{v}
where s and t are arbitrary numbers in \RNr.
’. Examples of span spaces include

li.para: the column space of an (m,n)-matrix \Mtrx{A}: the smallest subvector space of \RNr[m] containing all column vectors of \Mtrx{A}, and
the row space of an (m,n)-matrix \Mtrx{A}: the smallest subvector space of \RNr[n] containing all row vectors of \Mtrx{A}.

intro.para:
A second source of subspaces of \RNr[n] is the
orthogonal complement operation

When given a subvector space V of \RNr[n], one of the first things we want to know about it is its ‘size’; in other words, is it a line, a plane, a copy of \RNr[3], and so on? The ‘dimension’ of V provides such size information, that is the number of coordinate axes needed to describe the location of a point in V.

How do we set up a coordinate system in a subspace V of \RNr[n]? â€“ For each coordinate axis we choose one nonzero vector in the direction of the axis. The resulting collection of vectors is called a basis for V. Consequently, the number of vectors in a basis of V equals the dimension of V. – Let us describe this process in some more detail:

li.para: We start with a nonzero vector \Vect{b}_1 in V. Its span is the line of vectors t_1 \Vect{b}_1, where t_1 in \RNr is arbitrary. We take this line as the first coordinate axis. If this line is all of V, we are done. In this case V has dimension 1.

If the line found in step 1 is not all of V, there is a vector \Vect{b}_2 in V which does not lie on the line spanned by \Vect{b}_1. We take its span, that is all vectors of the form t_2 \Vect{b}_2 with t_2 in \RNr arbitrary, as the second coordinate axis.

Now the span of \Vect{b}_1 and \Vect{b}_2 is the plane in V consisting of all vectors of the form t_1 \Vect{b}_1 + t_2 \Vect{b}_2 with t_1, t_2 in \RNr arbitrary. If this plane is all of V, we are done. In this case V has dimension 2.

If the plane found in step 2) is not all of V, there is a vector \Vect{b}_3 in V which does not lie on the plane spanned by \Vect{b}_1,\Vect{b}_2. We take its span t_3 \Vect{b}_3 as the third coordinate axis.

Now the span of \Vect{b}_1,\Vect{b}_2,\Vect{b}_3 consists of all vectors of the form t_1 \Vect{b}_1 + t_2 \Vect{b}_2 + t_3 \Vect{b}_3 with t_1,t_2,t_3 in \RNr arbitrary. It is a three dimensional subspace of V. If this three dimensional subspace is all of V, we are done.

intro.para: The key point is that, for every subspace V of \RNr[n], this process stops after at most n steps, and we have a coordinate system for V whose number of coordinate axes is the dimension of V. – For this to make sense, we must prove somewhere that any two coordinate systems for V has the same number of coordinate axes.
We will learn how to express the vectors of V in terms of the vectors of a given basis of V.
